name: The Shire
description: The Shire is a peaceful, rural region inhabited by Hobbits, serving as the idyllic homeland in Middle-earth.

content.title: Overview
content.body: The Shire is a bucolic and pastoral territory located in the northwest of Middle-earth, inhabited predominantly by Hobbits, a small and peaceful folk who enjoy farming, craftsmanship, and simple living. The region is divided into four Farthings, featuring rolling hills, dense woods, and quaint villages. The Shire is a symbol of tranquility and the rustic charm of a simpler life, standing somewhat apart from the grander struggles and darker forces in the wider world.

content.title: Appearance
content.body: The Shire is characterized by lush green fields, gentle hills, and well-tended farmland. Its villages, such as Hobbiton, are comprised of cozy hobbit-holesâ€”homes built into hillsides with circular doors and windows, adorned with colorful gardens and neat pathways. The landscape exudes a sense of harmony with nature, with small streams, ancient trees, and flowering meadows enhancing its peaceful environment.

content.title: History
content.body: The Shire was established in the Third Age by Hobbits migrating from the East, who settled there with the permission of the King of Arnor. It remained largely unnoticed by the greater powers of Middle-earth, experiencing few conflicts or invasions. Although considered an insignificant corner of the world by others, the Shire is the starting point of 'The Lord of the Rings' saga, from which the journey to combat evil begins. Over time, the Shire became a refuge from the darkness that pervaded much of Middle-earth.

content.title: Story Significance
content.body: The Shire represents the innocence and home that the Fellowship fights to protect. It is the birthplace and refuge of key characters such as Frodo, Sam, Merry, and Pippin. As an emblem of peace and the simple joys of life, the Shire's fate is deeply connected to the larger struggle against Sauron's shadow. Its fate underscores the theme that even the smallest and humblest places bear great importance in the fight against evil.
